standard_metadata.standard_description: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

hints.content: Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\begin{align}\greenD{53{,}000}& \\ \blueD{350{,}000}& \end{align}$
$\greenD{53{,}000}$ has $0$ hundred thousands.  $\blueD{350{,}000}$ has $3$ hundred thousands.    $\greenD{53{,}000}$ has fewer hundred thousands, so it is less than $\blueD{350{,}000}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the ten thousands.    $\greenD{59{,}509}$ and $\blueD{59{,}950}$ both have $5$ ten thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{59{,}\underline509}& \\\\ \blueD{59{,}\underline950}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{59{,}509}$ has $5$ hundreds. $\blueD{59{,}950}$ has $9$ hundreds.     $\greenD{59{,}509}$ has fewer hundreds, so it is less than $\blueD{59{,}950}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the thousands.    $\greenD{8{,}381}$ and $\blueD{8{,}813}$ both have $8$ thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{8{,}\underline381}& \\\\ \blueD{8{,}\underline813}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{8{,}381}$ has $3$ hundreds. $\blueD{8{,}813}$ has $8$ hundreds.     $\greenD{8{,}381}$ has fewer hundreds, so it is less than $\blueD{8{,}813}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{624{,}188}$ and $\blueD{624{,}811}$ both have $6$ hundred thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{624{,}\underline188}& \\\\ \blueD{624{,}\underline811}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{624{,}188}$ has $1$ hundred. $\blueD{624{,}811}$ has $8$ hundreds.     $\greenD{624{,}188}$ has fewer hundreds, so it is less than $\blueD{624{,}811}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the ten thousands.    $\greenD{70{,}707}$ and $\blueD{71{,}177}$ both have $7$ ten thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{7\underline0{,}707}& \\\\ \blueD{7\underline1{,}177}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{70{,}707}$ has $0$ ten thousands. $\blueD{71{,}177}$ has $1$ ten thousand.     $\greenD{70{,}707}$ has fewer ten thousands, so it is less than $\blueD{71{,}177}$.
Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the millions.    $\begin{align}\greenD{229{,}680}& \\ \blueD{1{,}000{,}000}& \end{align}$
$\greenD{229{,}680}$ has $0$ millions.  $\blueD{1{,}000{,}000}$ has $1$ million.    $\greenD{229{,}680}$ has fewer millions, so it is less than $\blueD{1{,}000{,}000}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{644{,}900}$ and $\blueD{646{,}300}$ both have $6$ hundred thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{64\underline4{,}900}& \\ \blueD{64\underline6{,}300}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{644{,}900}$ has $4$ thousands. $\blueD{646{,}300}$ has $6$ thousands.     $\greenD{644{,}900}$ has fewer thousands, so it is less than $\blueD{646{,}300}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.  $\greenD{426{,}390}$ and $\blueD{426{,}930}$ both have $4$ hundred thousands.    What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{426{,}\underline390}& \\\\ \blueD{426{,}\underline930}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{426{,}390}$ has $3$ hundreds. $\blueD{426{,}930}$ has $9$ hundreds.     $\greenD{426{,}390}$ has fewer hundreds, so it is less than $\blueD{426{,}930}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the thousands.    $\greenD{5{,}532}$ and $\blueD{5{,}593}$ both have $5$ thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{5{,}5\underline32}& \\\\ \blueD{5{,}5\underline93}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{5{,}532}$ has $3$ tens. $\blueD{5{,}593}$ has $9$ tens.    $\greenD{5{,}532}$ has fewer tens, so it is less than $\blueD{5{,}593}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{622{,}400}$ and $\blueD{622{,}512}$ both have $6$ hundred thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{622{,}\underline400}& \\\\ \blueD{622{,}\underline512}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{622{,}400}$ has $4$ hundreds. $\blueD{622{,}512}$ has $5$ hundreds.    $\greenD{622{,}400}$ has fewer hundreds, so it is less than $\blueD{622{,}512}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{855{,}399}$ and $\blueD{854{,}244}$ both have $8$ hundred thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{85\underline5{,}399}& \\\\ \blueD{85\underline4{,}244}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{855{,}399}$ has $5$ thousands. $\blueD{854{,}244}$ has $4$ thousands.    $\greenD{855{,}399}$ has more thousands, so it is greater than $\blueD{854{,}244}$.
Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\begin{align}\greenD{453{,}298}& \\\\ \blueD{59{,}236}& \end{align}$
$\greenD{453{,}298}$ has $4$ hundred thousands.  $\blueD{59{,}236}$ has $0$ hundred thousands.    $\greenD{453{,}298}$ has more hundred thousands, so it is greater than $\blueD{59{,}236}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the thousands.    $\greenD{5{,}454}$ and $\blueD{5{,}445}$ both have $5$ thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{5{,}4\underline54}& \\\\ \blueD{5{,}4\underline45}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{5{,}454}$ has $5$ tens. $\blueD{5{,}445}$ has $4$ tens.    $\greenD{5{,}454}$ has more tens, so it is greater than $\blueD{5{,}445}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{555{,}050}$ and $\blueD{555{,}005}$ both have $5$ hundred thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{555{,}0\underline50}& \\\\ \blueD{555{,}0\underline05}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{555{,}050}$ has $5$ tens. $\blueD{555{,}005}$ has $0$ tens.    $\greenD{555{,}050}$ has more tens , so it is greater than $\blueD{555{,}005}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{422{,}241}$ and $\blueD{414{,}421}$ both have $4$ hundred thousands.    What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{4\underline22{,}241}& \\\\ \blueD{4\underline14{,}412}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{422{,}241}$ has $2$ ten thousands. $\blueD{414{,}421}$ has $1$ ten thousand.    $\greenD{422{,}241}$ has more ten thousands, so it is greater than $\blueD{414{,}421}$.
Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the thousands.    $\begin{align}\greenD{1{,}068}& \\\\ \blueD{875}& \end{align}$
$\greenD{1{,}068}$ has $1$ thousand.  $\blueD{875}$ has $0$ thousands.    $\greenD{1{,}068}$ has more thousands, so it is greater than $\blueD{875}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\greenD{606{,}160}$ and $\blueD{606{,}116}$ both have $6$ hundred thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{606{,}1\underline60}& \\\\ \blueD{606{,}1\underline16}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{606{,}160}$ has $6$ tens. $\blueD{606{,}116}$ has $1$ ten.    $\greenD{606{,}160}$ has more tens, so it is greater than $\blueD{606{,}116}$.
Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundred thousands.    $\begin{align} \greenD{\underline{7}11{,}211}\\\\ \blueD{\underline{1}72{,}227} \end{align}$
$\greenD{711{,}211}$ has $7$ hundred thousands. $\blueD{172{,}227}$ has $1$ hundred thousand.    $\greenD{711{,}211}$ has more hundred thousands, so it is greater than $\blueD{172{,}227}$.
Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the ten thousands.    $\begin{align}\greenD{74{,}333}& \\ \blueD{47{,}888}& \end{align}$
$\greenD{74{,}333}$ has $7$ ten thousands.  $\blueD{47{,}888}$ has $4$ ten thousands.    $\greenD{74{,}333}$ has more ten thousands, so it is greater than $\blueD{47{,}888}$.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the ten thousands.    $\greenD{98{,}989}$ and $\blueD{98{,}899}$ both have $9$ ten thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\begin{align}\greenD{98{,}\underline989}& \\\\ \blueD{98{,}\underline899}& \end{align}$  $\greenD{98{,}989}$ has $9$ hundreds. $\blueD{98{,}899}$ has $8$ hundreds.    $\greenD{98{,}989}$ has more hundreds, so it is greater than $\blueD{98{,}899}$.
Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the hundreds.  $\greenD{852}$ and $\blueD{852}$ both have $8$ hundreds.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\greenD{852}$ has $5$ tens. $\blueD{852}$ also has $5$ tens.    $\greenD{852}$ has $2$ ones. $\blueD{852}$ also has $2$ ones.    Both numbers have the same number of hundreds, tens, and ones, so they have equal values.
$\greenD{852}=\blueD{852}$

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the thousands.  $\greenD{3{,}497}$ and $\blueD{3{,}497}$ both have $3$ thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\greenD{3{,}497}$ has $4$ hundreds. $\blueD{3{,}497}$ also has $4$ hundreds.    $\greenD{3{,}497}$ has $9$ tens. $\blueD{3{,}497}$ also has $9$ tens.    $\greenD{3{,}497}$ has $7$ ones. $\blueD{3{,}497}$ also has $7$ ones.    Both numbers have the same number of thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones, so they have equal values.

Let's start by comparing the highest place value - the ten thousands.  $\greenD{65{,}931}$ and $\blueD{65{,}931}$ both have $6$ ten thousands.     What is the highest place value where the numbers have different digits?

$\greenD{65{,}931}$ has $5$ thousands. $\blueD{65{,}931}$ also has $5$ thousands.    $\greenD{65{,}931}$ has $9$ hundreds. $\blueD{65{,}931}$ also has $9$ hundreds.    $\greenD{65{,}931}$ has $3$ tens. $\blueD{65{,}931}$ also has $3$ tens.    $\greenD{65{,}931}$ has $1$ one. $\blueD{65{,}931}$ also has $1$ one.    Both numbers have the same number of ten thousands, thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones, so they have equal values.

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Hundreds | Tens | Ones :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: $\purpleC7$ | $\purpleC1$ | $\purpleC5$ $\blueD7$ | $\blueD5$ | $\blueD1$  $\greenD7$ | $\greenD5$ | $\greenD5$
$\blueD{715}<\purpleC{751}<\greenD{755}$    [[ explanation 1]]
The values from least to greatest:   $\blueD{715},\purpleC{751},\greenC{755}$

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Thousands | Hundreds | Tens | Ones :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: $\purpleC8$ | $\purpleC0$ | $\purpleC8$ | $\purpleC0$ $0$ | $\blueD8$ | $\blueD8$  | $\blueD0$  $\greenD8$ | $\greenD8$ | $\greenD0$ | $\greenD8$
$\blueD{880}<\purpleC{8{,}080}<\greenD{8{,}808}$    [[ explanation 1]]
The values from least to greatest:  $\blueD{880}, \purpleC{8{,}080}, \greenD{8{,}808}$

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Thousands | Hundreds | Tens | Ones :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: $\purpleC5$ | $\purpleC7$ | $\purpleC5$ | $\purpleC0$ $\blueD5$ | $\blueD0$ | $\blueD5$  | $\blueD7$  $\greenD7$ | $\greenD5$ | $\greenD0$ | $\greenD0$
$\blueD{5{,}057}<\purpleC{5{,}750}<\greenC{7{,}500}$    [[ explanation 1]]

$\blueD{313}<\purpleC{330}<\greenD{3{,}013}$    [[ explanation 1]]
